data.text:
122 years ago today, one of the big three American horror writers was born. Howard Phillips Lovecraft was born in Providence, Rhode Island on August 20, 1890. He lived for 47 years producing his highly original and influential horror stories and sharing them with other writers via the American amateur author network that was so popular in the early 1900’s.

The “big three American horror writers” began with Edgar Allan Poe, followed by H.P. Lovecraft, and finally Stephen King. King has acknowledged that Lovecraft was responsible for his interest in writing horror and the macabre. If you’ve never read any Lovecraft, he has a completely unique and identifiable style that you’ll never see anywhere else.

Lovecraft became my favorite author about 25 years ago when I picked up his long-story/short-novel “At the Mountains of Madness.” He was a prolific letter writer, poet, and of course a pioneer of horror fiction. If your a fan of horror fiction and have never read Lovecraft, you owe it to yourself to check him out. You might get hooked for life like me :-)

For more info check out: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HP_Lovecraft

PatchChord - 20 August 2012 11:19 PM

No confusion. Any H.P. Lovecraft recommendations?

Definitely…

Novellas: The Shadow Over Innsmouth, At the Mountains of Madness (these are probably my 2 favorites and either one is a great starting point)

Novels: The Case of Charles Dexter Ward

Short stories: The Festival, The Picture in the House, The Rats in the Walls, The Doom that Came to Sarnath, Nyarlathotep

Poems: Nathicana

One of the coolest things about Lovecraft is he defines a collection of places (Miskatonic University, Arkham, Innsmouth) ancient books (The Necronomicon) evil beings (Cthulhu, Nyarlathotep, Yog-Sothoth) and uses them interchangeably in his stories. This is defined as the “Cthulhu Mythos.” The only types of stories that I would recommend you stay away from (at least while starting out) are his “Dream Mythos” works like “The Dream Quest of Unknown Kadath” and “The Statement of Randolph Carter” as they can get a little tedious.

I’ve used Lovecraft’s stories as the basis for several of my best musical compositions. He presents such a unique atmosphere that it naturally lends itself to musical interpretation.

I’m happy to answer any other Lovecraft questions that arise! If I could turn someone else on to HPL, I’d have done my cosmic job :-)
